9.32.text:
There's something lurking in the shadows,
just hidden from view.

14.58.text:
Do you believe in ghosts?
Because we do.

18.18.text: And they're causing quite a problem for all of us here in the UK.

22.18.text:
We're Her Majesty's Revenue & Customs
- HMRC for short.

25.92.text:
We're the UK's tax authority and we know
all about ghosts

30.33.text: and what's more, we're tracking them down.

33.69.text:
These ghosts aren't the spooky, supernatural
variety,

36.64.text:
but they, and a similar group called moonlighters,
are good at hiding - becoming invisible - when

43.58.text:
'Ghosts' and 'moonlighters' are the
names that are often given to people who contribute

47.78.text: to what's called the UK's hidden economy.

51.12.text: You might have read about them in the newspaper or online.

55.20.text:
They're the small minority of people who
ignore the law, by keeping all or part of

59.64.text:
what they earn hidden away in order to avoid
paying tax.

63.66.text:
And it's because they keep their earnings
hidden that we describe what they do as the

69.78.text: So let's look at these people a bit more closely.

72.80.text: The people who keep all their income hidden

74.56.text:
from HMRC are often called tax 'ghosts'.
And they break the law by pocketing all the

80.38.text: money they should be paying in tax.

83.90.text: 'Moonlighters' are people who pay tax on some, but not all, of their earnings.

88.60.text: They could be electricians, taxi drivers,

91.05.text:
doctors, landlords, artists, IT whizzes or
anything else for that matter

95.92.text:
They're ordinary people doing regular jobs
but....the reason they only pay tax on

101.25.text:
some of the income is because they also do
work 'on the side' - perhaps in the

106.16.text:
evenings or at weekends.
And that's the bit they keep hidden from

109.75.text:
HMRC,
pretending they earn less money than they

112.81.text:
actually do,
and paying less in taxes than they should.

117.52.text:
These tax cheats could be operating in your
city, in your town, even in your street.

127.56.text:
Well, we think you should,
and here's why.

130.62.text:
When ghosts and moonlighters cheat HMRC, the
people they're really cheating are you.

135.79.text:
The money they should have paid in taxes would
have been used by the government

139.42.text:
to build schools and colleges; to pay your
teachers' salaries;

141.53.text: to save and improve people's lives through the health service;

145.76.text: to fight crime and defend our country.

148.83.text:
But instead, the people who operate in the
hidden economy have decided they should spend

153.38.text:
that money on themselves.
And they hold on to more than £5 billion

158.30.text:
every year - money that should have been paid
in taxes to help everyone.

162.51.text:
Leaving the rest of us to pay more for the
vital services we all rely on

166.88.text: for our health, education, safety and security.

171.42.text:
Not paying taxes can also give dishonest people
an unfair advantage,

175.86.text:
because the person who's cheating by not
paying tax

178.10.text:
may be able to charge less for the goods and
services they sell.

182.01.text:
And this means that in undercutting prices,
they take customers away from honest businesses.

187.02.text:
And we're sure you'll agree, that's
just not fair.

191.23.text: This is why the hidden economy is a real problem.

193.74.text:
So what is HMRC doing to track down the ghosts
and moonlighters?

199.36.text:
Well, we know that some people may slip into
the hidden economy without realising it.

204.54.text:
For example, they don't realise that what
started out as a hobby - perhaps buying

208.70.text:
and selling things on the internet - has
now become a business, on which they should

212.37.text:
pay tax.
HMRC helps those people through education

216.47.text:
and publicity campaigns, so they understand
when they do need to pay tax.

220.75.text:
But for the people who try to stay hidden
and who refuse to come out of the shadows,

226.28.text:
HMRC has teams of top investigators - hundreds
of them - whose job it is to search out

234.01.text:
The investigators use lots of different information
and techniques,

237.65.text:
ranging from tax inspectors, who operate undercover
to identify suspicious behaviour,

242.69.text:
to a powerful new fraud-busting computer system
called 'Connect',

246.60.text:
which brings together information from lots
of different sources.

250.45.text:
Connect helps HMRC to find the patterns and
links in one billion pieces of data.

255.45.text:
By looking at bank accounts, loans, addresses,
tax and employment details - even using

259.78.text:
Google Earth to check if people's lifestyles
are consistent with the amount they say they

263.78.text:
earn - HMRC can identify the people who aren't
paying the right amount of tax

When they're caught, the ghosts and moonlighters

274.01.text:
interest, and financial penalties - and
they're often 'named and shamed' in

278.94.text: In serious cases, they can even be sent to prison.

Well, you could be starting your first job
soon - maybe a part-time Saturday job or a

291.68.text:
holiday job - and you need to know the dangers
to look out for.

298.96.text: if your new boss doesn't ask you to complete

301.26.text: any paperwork when you start work;

303.40.text: doesn't ask you for your National Insurance number;

305.54.text: pays you in cash and doesn't give you a payslip;

307.86.text: or asks you not to mention what you're

311.65.text:
This is important.
You don't want to start off your working

314.10.text:
life 'in the shadows', as part of the
hidden economy.

317.31.text:
If your boss isn't paying taxes, they won't
be making National Insurance Contributions

321.28.text:
either, to entitle you to certain benefits,
including (in a few decades' time) your pension.

327.60.text:
And we don't want to worry you, but if they're
ignoring the tax rules, they might also be

331.46.text:
ignoring other important things, such as health
and safety checks, and insurance cover,

336.15.text:
which is important in case something goes
wrong and you have an accident at work.

340.82.text: If you're worried you should speak to an adult you trust

343.90.text: and if they're concerned they can contact HMRC.

347.02.text: When it comes to your career, be smart, protect yourself

350.62.text: and keep well away from ghosts!
